law.full_text:
ILLEGALLY MOORED OR ABANDONED VESSELS.
If any unattended vessel shall be found to be anchored or moored within the entrance channel, the Director may assume custody of such vessel and cause it to be removed or held or placed in storage. The Director or his deputies shall not be held liable for any damage to such vessel whether such damage occurs before or after he assumes custody.
If said vessel is not claimed by the owner thereof, the Director may deal with such vessel in the manner as provided in the Civil Code as it now reads or as it may hereafter be amended.

unit.catch_line: Permits For Races And Special Events.
Anchoring Or Mooring In Entrance Channel.
Fees Incidental To Recovery, Movement And Storage.
Dangerous Vessels, Sunken Vessels, Or Obstruction Of Channels.
Prohibited Operation Upon Waters Of The Channel.
Prohibited Activities Upon Areas Abutting The Entrance Channel.

law.plain_text:
LOS ANGELES MUNICIPAL CODE
ILLEGALLY MOORED OR ABANDONED VESSELS. (§ 69.15)
ILLEGALLY MOORED OR ABANDONED VESSELS. If any unattended vessel shall be found to be anchored or moored within the entrance channel, the Director may assume custody of such vessel and cause it to be removed or held or placed in storage. The Director or his deputies shall not be held liable for any damage to such vessel whether such damage occurs before or after he assumes custody. If said vessel is not claimed by the owner thereof, the Director may deal with such vessel in the manner as provided in the Civil Code as it now reads or as it may hereafter be amended.
